change.li: $Log: encyclopedia.xml,v $ Revision 1.28 2006/03/27 14:02:23 gcrane more refinements Revision 1.27 2006/03/26 04:13:20 gcrane more fixes Revision 1.26 2006/03/25 19:26:47 gcrane more fixes Revision 1.25 2006/03/25 16:38:06 gcrane Did a lot of work to clean up the base headers for subentries. These should more often now only include global descriptions, e.g, PERSON, son of A stays, but PERSON, fought at Troy goes. --> "Fought at Troy" can be one of many events and is not a global identifier Revision 1.24 2006/03/20 19:15:42 gcrane cleaned up the formatting Revision 1.23 2006/03/20 14:15:22 gcrane small changes Revision 1.20 2006/03/18 15:34:36 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.19 2006/03/18 01:14:23 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.18 2006/03/17 23:55:18 gaweaver small fixes Revision 1.17 2006/03/17 21:56:39 gaweaver Calliopi From Antiphon until Chilon Revision 1.16 2006/03/17 15:39:04 gaweaver no message Revision 1.15 2006/03/10 00:01:20 gaweaver changes made by GRC while over the atlantic Revision 1.14 2006/03/05 03:47:42 gcrane base file Revision 1.13 2006/03/04 13:13:03 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.12 2006/03/03 18:21:05 gaweaver Agenor (10) Revision 1.11 2006/02/15 16:24:46 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.10 2006/02/13 21:52:23 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.9 2006/02/13 01:57:42 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.8 2006/02/12 23:12:05 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.7 2006/02/12 15:30:08 gcrane major structural update: the descriptive info has now been moved up into the headers and id's added to div1 type="entry" Revision 1.6 2006/02/12 13:23:59 gcrane moved descriptions up into the header: the goal is to make the header more informative and thus to facilitate the mechanics of aligning entries in this list with those in Smith's etc Revision 1.5 2006/02/11 19:49:21 gcrane more small fixes to make the coding consistent Revision 1.4 2006/02/11 18:50:04 gcrane working towards moving identifiers for all entities up into the subentry HEAD Revision 1.3 2006/02/10 22:43:14 gcrane changed the structure so that every entry has a subentry -- this simplifies the structure (i hope) Revision 1.2 2005/08/18 13:53:45 packel item tags... Revision 1.1 2005/07/25 14:32:52 packel Converted to XML Revision 1.34 2003/07/01 22:16:05 yorkc Updated texts to TEI P4 and Perseus P4 extensions; minor cleanup (esp. character encodings and typos.) Revision 1.33 2000/03/16 03:17:12 dasmith Gave homonym entries a top-level header. Revision 1.32 2000/03/16 02:52:18 dasmith Added alphabetic letter DIV0s. Made entries subordinate to alphabetic letters in refsDecl. Revision 1.31 2000/03/15 15:12:45 amahoney make homonyms sub-entries Revision 1.30 2000/03/14 18:11:05 amahoney several more random issues, but the Apollodorus refs really are right now Revision 1.27 2000/03/04 20:34:25 dasmith Added separate funder entity to TEI header. Revision 1.26 2000/02/22 17:17:30 amahoney fix bibl refs to known works Revision 1.25 2000/02/04 17:58:05 dasmith Primary lookup by ID (mostly useful for internal navigation). Revision 1.24 2000/01/10 21:09:41 acsmith trying again to change pilaster def. Revision 1.23 2000/01/10 20:16:54 dasmith Fixed sentence grammar. Revision 1.22 1999/10/01 14:11:04 acsmith Amy did away with dangling ref. to Type A2 cup, and turned all Type A1 cups into Type A cups, and lower cased type in Proto type A cup. Revision 1.21 1999/09/30 21:52:22 dasmith Fixed amphorae cross-refs. Revision 1.20 1999/09/30 21:08:38 acsmith ACS fixed (hopefully!) amphorae and pyxides Revision 1.19 1999/09/29 15:55:28 dasmith Converted to TEI2 tagging.

ul.li: its acropolis called Psophis: Paus. 8.24.3
suitors of Penelope from: Apollod. E.7.25, Apollod. E.7.29
west of Greece, description of a pool there: Hdt. 4.195
Demaratus' escape there: Hdt. 6.70
intended expulsion of Zacynthians by Samians: Hdt. 3.59
death of Hegesistratus in Zacynthus: Hdt. 9.37

div2.subhead: Zancle, city of Sicily captured by Anaxilas and Messenians

ul.li: its name altered to Messene: Paus. 4.23.9, Paus. 5.25.11
its seizure by Samians (later Messene, modern Messina): Hdt. 6.23, Hdt. 7.164
attack by Hippocrates of Gela: Hdt. 7.154

div2.subhead: Zanes, images of Zeus at Olympia made from fines

ul.li: belongs to Free Laconians: Paus. 3.21.7, Paus. 3.24.1
his shrine: Paus. 1.38.4

div2.subhead: Zaueces, a tribe in western Libya

ul.li: Spirit of the: Paus. 1.24.3
philosopher: Paus. 1.29.15, Paus. 2.8.4
altar of: Paus. 1.37.2

div2.subhead: Zethus, son of Epopeus and Antiope

ul.li: son of Zeus by Antiope, twin brother of Amphion: Apollod. 3.5.5, Apollod. vol. 1. 339
with his brother Amphion founds Thebes: Paus. 2.6.4
pays attention to cattlebreeding: Apollod. 3.5.5
marries Thebe: Apollod. 3.5.5
father of Neis: Paus. 9.8.4
son of Zethus slain by his mother: Paus. 9.5.9
Zethus dies brokenhearted: Paus. 9.5.9
common tomb of Amphion and Zethus at Thebes: Paus. 9.17.4, Paus. 10.32.11
Tithoreans steal earth from the tomb to fertilise their land: Paus. 9.17.4
son of Cronus and Rhea: Apollod. 1.1.4
child of Cronus and Rhea, saved from his father's maw by ruse of Rhea: Paus. 8.8.2, Paus. 8.36.3, Paus. 9.2.7, Paus. 9.41.6, Paus. 10.24.6
born in a cave of Dicte in Crete: Apollod. 1.1.4
born and brought up in Messenia on Mount Lycaeus: Paus. 4.33.1, Paus. 8.36.3, Paus. 8.38.2
at birth washed in Gortynius river: Paus. 8.28.2
fed by nymphs: Apollod. 1.1.4
guarded by Curetes: Apollod. 1.1.4, Apollod. 1.1.7
entrusted for safety at birth to Idaean Dactyls or Curetes by Rhea: Paus. 4.33.1, Paus. 5.7.6
makes war on the Titans: Apollod. 1.1.7, Apollod. 1.2.1
releases the Cyclopes from Tartarus and receives thunder and lightning from them: Apollod. 1.2.1
smites the giants with a thunderbolt: Apollod. 1.6.1, Apollod. 1.6.2
shuts up the Titans in Tartarus: Apollod. 1.2.1
wrestles at Olympia with Cronus for kingdom: Paus. 5.7.10, Paus. 8.2.2
casts lots with his brothers Poseidon and Pluto for the sovereignty: Apollod. 1.2.1
allotted the dominion of the sky: Apollod. 1.2.1
reigns in the three realms of nature -- sky, earth, and sea: Paus. 2.24.4
and Poseidon rivals for the hand of Thetis: Apollod. 3.13.4
ordains oaths by the water of Styx: Apollod. 1.2.2
Hermes servant of Zeus: Paus. 8.32.4
prayed to for rain: Paus. 1.24.3, Paus. 2.29.8
jar of blessings and jar of woes at his side: Paus. 8.24.14
in love with maiden Hera: Paus. 2.17.4
changes himself into a cuckoo: Paus. 2.17.4, Paus. 2.36.1
reconciled to Hera by stratagem: Paus. 9.3.1ff.
marries Hera: Apollod. 1.2.6
on his marriage receives the apples of the Hesperides from Earth: Apollod. 2.5.11
and Hera refer their dispute to Tiresias as arbiter: Apollod. 3.10.167
grants Tiresias the art of soothsaying: Apollod. 3.10.167
hangs Hera from Olympus: Apollod. 1.3.5, Apollod. 2.6.4
casts Hephaestus out of heaven: Apollod. 1.3.5

his intrigues with Callisto: Paus. 1.25.1, Paus. 8.3.6, with Carme: Paus. 2.30.3, with Io: Paus. 1.25.1, with Lamia: Paus. 10.12.1, with Niobe: Paus. 2.22.5, with Pluto: Paus. 2.22.3, with Semele: Paus. 3.24.3, with Taygete: Paus. 3.1.2, with Thebe: Paus. 5.22.6
his offspring: Apollod. 1.2.6, Apollod. 1.3.1

father of Aethlius: Paus. 5.1.3, of Agdistis: Paus. 7.17.10, of Argus: Paus. 2.22.5, Paus. 2.26.2, of Britomartis: Paus. 2.30.3, of Dionysus: Paus. 3.24.3, of Graces: Paus. 9.35.5, of Helen: Paus. 1.33.7, of Lacedaemon: Paus. 3.1.2, of Megareus: Paus. 1.40.1, of younger Muses: Paus. 9.29.4, of Opportunity: Paus. 5.14.9, of Pirithous: Paus. 5.10.8, of the Seasons: Paus. 5.11.7, of Tantalus: Paus. 2.22.3
father of Hellen by Pyrrha: Apollod. 1.7.2, Apollod. 1.7.3
of Aethlius by Protogenia: Apollod. 1.7.3
father of Castor and Pollux by Leda: Apollod. 1.8.2, Apollod. 1.9.17
has intercourse with Metis: Apollod. 1.3.5
swallows the pregnant Metis: Apollod. 1.3.5, Apollod. 1.3.6
Athena born from his head: Apollod. 1.3.6, Paus. 1.24.2
makes love to Asteria: Apollod. 1.3.6
father of Pan by Hybris: Apollod. 1.4.1
father of Tityus by Elare: Apollod. 1.4.1, Apollod. 1.4.1
father of Iasion and Dardanus by Electra: Apollod. 1.4.5
carries off Aegina, daughter of Asopus: Apollod. 1.9.2, Paus. 2.5.1, Paus. 2.29.2
carries off Aegina and has a son Aeacus by her: Apollod. 3.12.5, Apollod. 3.12.6
hurls thunderbolts at Asopus: Apollod. 3.12.6
seduces Io and turns her into a white cow: Apollod. 2.1.3
orders Hermes to steal Io: Apollod. 2.1.3
father of Argus and Pelasgus by Niobe: Apollod. 1.9.28, Apollod. 2.1.1, Apollod. 3.7.7
in shape of stream of gold impregnates Danae: Apollod. 2.4.1
his prediction concerning the descendant of Perseus: Apollod. 2.4.5
in likeness of Amphitryo lies with Alcmena: Paus. 5.18.3
in likeness of Amphitryon begets Herakles on Alcmena: Apollod. 2.4.7, Apollod. 2.4.8
father of Rhadamanthys: Apollod. 2.4.11
Prometheus offers himself to Zeus to be immortal instead of Chiron: Apollod. 2.5.4, Apollod. 2.5.11, Apollod. 1.3.51
Europa ferried by bull for: Apollod. 2.5.6
parts Apollo and Herakles: Apollod. 2.6.2
rescues wounded Herakles: Apollod. 2.6.4
Cenaean, altar of: Apollod. 2.7.7
Paternal, altars of: Apollod. 2.8.3
as a bull, carries Europa to Crete: Apollod. 3.1.1
begets Minos, Sarpedon, and Rhadamanthys by Europa: Apollod. 3.1.1
grants Sarpedon to live for three generations: Apollod. 3.1.2
father of Atymnius by Cassiepea: Apollod. 3.1.2
Atabyrian, altar of: Apollod. 3.1.4
gives Harmonia in marriage to Cadmus : Apollod. 3.4.2
gives necklace to Europa: Apollod. 3.4.2
loves Semele: Apollod. 3.4.2
visits her with thunder and lightning: Apollod. 3.4.3
sews up the abortive infant Dionysus in his thigh: Apollod. 3.4.3
gives birth to Dionysus in due time and entrusts him to Hermes: Apollod. 3.4.3
turns Dionysus into a kid: Apollod. 3.4.3
father of Amphion and Zethus by Antiope: Apollod. 3.5.5, Apollod. 3.5.5, Apollod. 1.1.2
Niobe prays to: Apollod. 3.5.6
kills Capaneus with a thunderbolt: Apollod. 3.10.167
cleaves the earth by a thunderbolt: Apollod. 3.12.21
makes Amphiaraus immortal: Apollod. 3.12.21
consorts with Callirrhoe and grants that her sons should be suddenly full grown: Apollod. 3.10.185
in disguise visits Lycaon and his sons, is tempted by them with human sacrifices, and blasts them by thunderbolts: Apollod. 3.12.31, Apollod. 3.12.33
in the likeness of Artemis or Apollo forces Callisto, turns her into a bear, then into the constellation called the Bear: Apollod. 3.12.35, Apollod. 3.12.37
gives her child Arcas to Maia to bring up: Apollod. 3.12.37
Melanion and Atalanta have intercourse in a precinct of: Apollod. vol. 2.401
consorts with the daughters of Atlas: Apollod. 3.10.1
father of Hermes by Maia: Apollod. 3.10.1
orders Hermes to restore the stolen kine to Apollo: Apollod. 3.10.2
father of Lacedaemon by Taygete: Apollod. 3.10.2
smites Aesculapius with a thunderbolt to prevent men from learning the healing art: Apollod. 3.10.3
Cyclopes forge thunderbolts for: Apollod. 3.10.3
orders Apollo to serve a man for a year as expiation for the slaughter of the Cyclopes: Apollod. 3.10.3, Apollod. 3.10.4
as a swan consorts with Leda and begets Pollux and Helen: Apollod. 3.10.5
according to others, he got Helen on Nemesis: Apollod. 3.10.7
smites Idas with a thunderbolt: Apollod. 3.11.2
raises Pollux to heaven: Apollod. 3.11.2
allows Castor and Pollux to be among gods and mortals on alternate days: Apollod. 3.11.2
Ganymede carried off to be cup-bearer to Zeus: Paus. 5.24.5
carries off Ganymede on an eagle and makes him cupbearer to the gods: Apollod. 3.12.2
gives the Palladium as a sign to Ilus: Apollod. 3.12.3
interposes the aegis between Athena and Pallas: Apollod. 3.12.3
throws the Palladium into the Ilian country: Apollod. 3.12.3
father of Asopus by Eurynome: Apollod. 3.12.5
helps Pluto to carry off Persephone: Apollod. 1.4.5
culls a magic simple: Apollod. 1.6.1
inspires Porphyrion with lust for Hera: Apollod. 1.6.1
his combat with Typhon: Apollod. 1.6.3, Apollod. 1.6.3
his sinews cut by Typhon and restored by Hermes and Aegipan: Apollod. 1.6.3, Apollod. 1.6.3
casts Etna on Typhon: Apollod. 1.6.3
orders Hephaestus to nail Prometheus to the Caucasus: Apollod. 1.7.1
resolves to destroy the men of the Bronze Age and causes the great flood: Apollod. 1.7.1, Apollod. 1.7.2

sends Hermes to Deucalion: Apollod. 1.7.2
bids Deucalion throw stones over his head: Apollod. 1.7.2
turns Ceyx and Alcyone into birds for their presumption: Apollod. 1.7.4
claim of Ceyx to be: Apollod. 1.7.4
gives Endymion his choice: Apollod. 1.7.5
parts Apollo and Idas: Apollod. 1.7.7
makes Oeneus fall in love with his own daughter: Apollod. 1.8.3

Salmoneus's mimickry of: Apollod. 1.9.5, Apollod. 1.9.5
kills Salmoneus by a thunderbolt: Apollod. 1.9.5, Apollod. 1.9.5
kills Salmoneus by a thunderbolt: Apollod. 1.9.5
angry with the Argonauts for the murder of Apsyrtus: Apollod. 1.9.23, Apollod. 1.9.24
orders Athena and Hermes to purify the Danaids: Apollod. 2.1.5
turns vixen and dog to stone: Apollod. 2.4.7
turns ants into men for Aeacus: Apollod. 3.12.6
changes the nymphs at Nysa into the Hyades: Apollod. 3.4.3
angry with Actaeon for wooing Semele: Apollod. 3.4.3
instigates Actaeon's dogs to devour him: Apollod. 3.4.4
sends Cadmus and Harmonia to the Elysian Fields: Apollod. 3.5.4
appoints arbiters between Poseidon and Athena in the dispute for the possession of Attica: Apollod. 3.14.1, Apollod. 3.14.1

Minos prays for vengeance on Athens to: Apollod. 3.15.8
makes a cloud in the likeness of Hera and lays it beside Ixion: Apollod. E.1.20
binds Ixion to a wheel: Apollod. E.1.20

wills that Europe and Asia should be embroiled: Apollod. E.2.15

div2.subhead: Zeuxippe(2), mother's sister and wife of Pandion

ul.li: mother of Procne and Philomela: Apollod. 3.14.7

div2.subhead: Zeuxippus, son of Apollo and Syllis

ul.li: king of Sicyon: Paus. 2.6.7

div3.p: Literally meaning "bearing animals"; a word applied to a panel or relief, and hence used to describe the continuous carved frieze of Ionic and Corinthian architecture, which represents the triglyphs and metopes of the Doric buildings.

ul.li: son of Megabyzus, his pretended desertion to the Babylonians, and delivery of Babylon to Darius: Hdt. 3.153-159
Darius' esteem for him: Hdt. 3.160
rape of his daughter: Hdt. 4.43
his migration from Persia to Athens: Hdt. 3.160
"Girdle," a promontory on the coast of Attica, rocks near it taken for ships by the Persians: Hdt. 8.10
founds Astacus: Paus. 5.12.7
